questions.question: A ___ sentence consists of one main or independent clause.
questions.explanation: A simple sentence has only one independent clause with one finite verb.

questions.question: A ___ sentence has two or more clauses of equal importance joined by coordinating conjunctions.
questions.explanation: A compound sentence joins independent clauses using and, but, or, so, etc.

questions.question: A ___ sentence consists of a main clause and one or more subordinate clauses.
questions.explanation: A complex sentence has a main clause and at least one dependent clause.

questions.question: A sentence that makes a statement is called an ___ sentence.
questions.explanation: An assertive or declarative sentence makes a statement or declaration.

questions.question: A sentence that asks a question is called an ___ sentence.
questions.explanation: An interrogative sentence asks a question and ends with a question mark.

questions.question: A sentence that expresses strong feeling is called an ___ sentence.
questions.explanation: An exclamatory sentence expresses strong emotions like joy, surprise, or sorrow.

questions.question: A sentence that gives a command or makes a request is called an ___ sentence.
questions.explanation: An imperative sentence gives commands, orders, requests, or advice.

questions.question: The words 'and', 'but', 'or', 'so' are called ___ conjunctions.
questions.explanation: Coordinating conjunctions join clauses of equal importance.

questions.question: The words 'because', 'although', 'when', 'if' are called ___ conjunctions.
questions.explanation: Subordinating conjunctions introduce dependent clauses.

questions.question: When we change a sentence from one type to another without changing its meaning, it is called ___ of a sentence.
questions.explanation: Transformation of sentences means converting between sentence types while keeping the same meaning.

questions.question: A clause that can stand alone and make complete sense is called an ___ clause.
questions.explanation: An independent or main clause expresses a complete thought.

questions.question: A clause that depends on the main clause for its meaning is called a ___ clause.
questions.explanation: A subordinate or dependent clause cannot stand alone.

questions.question: 'What' is used to begin exclamatory sentences with ___ or noun phrases.
questions.explanation: Example: What a beautiful day! ('day' is a noun)

questions.question: 'How' is used to begin exclamatory sentences with ___ or adverbs.
questions.explanation: Example: How beautiful! (beautiful is an adjective) or How quickly! (quickly is an adverb)

questions.question: When changing assertive to interrogative, a positive statement often becomes a ___ question.
questions.explanation: Example: 'It is good' becomes 'Isn't it good?'

questions.question: When changing interrogative to assertive, 'nobody' or 'nothing' often becomes '___' or 'everything'.
questions.explanation: Rhetorical questions with 'Who doesn't...' become 'Everybody/Everyone...'

questions.question: 'Too...to' in a simple sentence becomes 'so...___' in a complex sentence.
questions.explanation: Example: 'too weak to walk' becomes 'so weak that he cannot walk'

questions.question: The coordinating conjunctions can be remembered by the acronym ___.
questions.explanation: FANBOYS: For, And, Nor, But, Or, Yet, So

questions.question: A clause beginning with 'who', 'which', or 'that' describing a noun is called a ___ clause.
questions.explanation: Relative (adjective) clauses describe or modify nouns.

questions.question: To change a participial phrase to a clause, we add a ___ and change the participle to a finite verb.
questions.explanation: Example: 'Having finished work' becomes 'After he finished work'

questions.question: Identify the type: 'She sings well.' - This is a ___ sentence.
questions.explanation: One subject (She) and one finite verb (sings) = simple sentence.

questions.question: Identify the type: 'He was late, so he missed the bus.' - This is a ___ sentence.
questions.explanation: Two independent clauses joined by 'so' = compound sentence.

questions.question: Identify the type: 'If you work hard, you will succeed.' - This is a ___ sentence.
questions.explanation: Main clause + subordinate clause (If you work hard) = complex sentence.

questions.question: The conjunction '___ ' is used to show contrast in compound sentences.
questions.explanation: 'But' and 'yet' show contrast between two ideas.

questions.question: The conjunction '___ ' is used to show cause/reason in compound sentences.
questions.explanation: 'For' shows reason, 'so' shows result.

questions.question: Exclamatory: 'What a tall building it is!' Assertive: 'It is a ___ tall building.'
questions.explanation: We add 'very' to maintain the emphasis when changing to assertive.

questions.question: Assertive: 'He works hard.' Exclamatory: '___ hard he works!'
questions.explanation: 'How' is used with adverbs (hard) in exclamatory sentences.

questions.question: In the sentence 'The man who called is my uncle', 'who called' is an ___ clause.
questions.explanation: The clause describes/modifies the noun 'man'.

questions.question: In the sentence 'I know that he is honest', 'that he is honest' is a ___ clause.
questions.explanation: The clause acts as the object of 'know'.

questions.question: In the sentence 'When he came, I was reading', 'When he came' is an ___ clause.
questions.explanation: The clause tells us when the action happened (modifies the verb).

questions.question: Simple: 'Despite his efforts, he failed.' Compound: 'He made efforts, ___ he failed.'
questions.explanation: 'Despite' shows contrast, which becomes 'but' or 'yet' in compound form.

questions.question: Complex: 'When the rain stopped, we went out.' Simple: 'After the ___ of rain, we went out.'
questions.explanation: The time clause becomes a prepositional phrase with a gerund.

questions.question: Simple: 'Being ill, she stayed home.' Complex: '___ she was ill, she stayed home.'
questions.explanation: The participial phrase becomes a causal clause with Because/Since/As.

questions.question: Compound: 'Work hard, or you will fail.' Simple: 'Work hard to ___ failure.'
questions.explanation: 'Or you will fail' becomes an infinitive of purpose: 'to avoid failure'.

questions.question: Assertive: 'Nobody can deny this.' Interrogative: '___ can deny this?'
questions.explanation: 'Nobody' becomes 'Who' in rhetorical questions implying 'nobody'.

questions.question: Interrogative: 'Is there anything more precious than health?' Assertive: 'There is ___ more precious than health.'
questions.explanation: The rhetorical question implies 'nothing', which appears in the assertive.

questions.question: A simple sentence can have more than one subject but only one ___ verb.
questions.explanation: A simple sentence has one finite (main) verb, though it may have non-finite verbs.

questions.question: 'Although', 'because', 'if', 'when' are examples of ___ conjunctions.
questions.explanation: These conjunctions introduce dependent/subordinate clauses.

questions.question: Simple: 'He is too weak to walk.' Complex: 'He is ___ weak that he cannot walk.'
questions.explanation: 'Too...to' structure becomes 'so...that' in complex sentences.

questions.question: Simple: 'On hearing the news, she cried.' Complex: '___ she heard the news, she cried.'
questions.explanation: 'On hearing' (prepositional phrase with gerund) becomes a time clause.
